Cotrimoxazole

III-Cotrimoxazole The combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole, called cotrimoxazole shows greater antimicrobial activity than equivalent quantities of either drug used alone.The combination was selected because of the similarity in the half-lives of the two drugs. Rationally, by blocking the first stepin folic acid synthesis, there is no real reason to block further steps. However, there are some bacteria which can inhibits the initial blockage, and so this may be the rationale for the use of such combination. -There is synergy between the two drugs - the combined effect is greater that the expected sum of their activities -Individually the drugs are bacteriostatic; however, in combination they are bactericidal -The use of two drugs will delay the emergence of resistance.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male with chronic h/o ulcerative colitis has been prescribed the drug sulfasalazine. The mechanism of development of resistance against this drug is by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Altered metabolic pathway

Highyeild:

Sulfasalazine being a sulfonamide develop resistance by the following mechanisms: Produce increased amounts of PABA Their folate synthase enzyme has a low affinity for sulfonamides Adopt an alternative pathway in folate metabolism.

Random:

Enzymatic breakdown: aminoglycosides, beta-lactams & chloramphenicol develop resistance by this mechanism. Option: D . Decreased permeability: aminoglycosides develop resistance by this mechanism.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient has been prescribed the drug cotrimoxazole. In this drug, trimethoprim is combined with sulfamethoxazole in a ratio of 1:5 to yield a steady-state plasma concentration ratio of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trimethoprim 1: sulfamethoxazole 20

Highyeild:

Optimal synergy in the case of most organisms is exhibited at a concentration ratio of sulfamethoxazole 20: trimethoprim 1. This ratio is obtained in the plasma when the two are given in a dose ratio of 5: 1, because trimethoprim is more lipid soluble, enters many tissues, has a larger volume of distribution than sulfamethoxazole & attains lower plasma concentration.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male has been suffering from an infection. The doctor wants to target the microbe metabolism by giving a drug which interferes with it. He wants to inhibit the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (dhfr). The following drugs can be given to inhibit this enzyme except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sulfonamide Sulfonamide is a functional group (a part of a molecule) that is the basis of several groups of drugs, which are called sulphonamides, sulfa drugs or sulpha drugs. The original antibacterial sulfonamides are synthetic (nonantibiotic) antimicrobial agents that contain the sulfonamide group.

Highyeild:

Sulfonamides antibacterial agents Sulfa drugs were discovered when a red dye called prontosil has shown in-vivo antibacterial activity while it was in-vitro inactive. This supports the idea that prontosil to exert its action, it has to be activated by the host metabolic pathways to give the active form. Sulfonamides are competitive inhibitors of dihydropteroate synthase (not dhfr), the bacterial enzyme responsible for the incorporation of PABA into dihydropteroic acid, the immediate precursor of folic acid.

Pyrimethamine is an antimalarial drug which inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (dhf rase). Methotrexate is an anti-cancer drug which inhibits dhf rase.
